posts.sub: Help removing giant iron cross from local mountain
posts.com:
There's this really nice mountain where people go to exercise and enjoy nature.

The view from the top is stunning and I like to drive there sometimes with friends just to hang out away from society.

But of course, some catholic dipshits had to erect a 6 meter iron cross with the inscription "I will reign over Spain" just to get themselves off.

Fucking thing isn't even that big, but it's visible from the highway going out of town and it absolutely kills the mood at night having a creepy cross looming over the city.

Any advice for taking it down? I just wanna push it down the hill. I doubt they'll bother to get it back on top, and if they do, I'll just take it down again.

Already tried a shovel to no luck. Maybe a pickaxe would do the trick?

Good luck

posts.sub: Faking it but not making it
posts.com: I already have future plans and ambitions for myself but i'm having a hard time coming to grips with the consequences I have to face if I wished to accomplish my goals. It took me until now to understand my mental disability in the form of high functioning autism (aspergers). If I wished to ever survive in modern day society I have to hide my autistic behaviors and pretend I'm neurotypical. Though it can grant me opprtunities like friends, relationships, and jobs I will have to deal with low self-esteem, depression, exhaustion, suicidal ideation, and loss of identity. I'm going to slowly lose myself in the process. Even if I can form relationships with my peers I will still be isolated, because no one will ever know who the real me is. Every moment I will be in a state of discomfort so at every possible chance I get I will look for the opportunity to excuse myself and take in a fresh breath of air or breakdown alone. Masking will also leave me vulnerable to abuse because it will force me to become a passive people pleaser. I know I am capable of pulling off this strategy and it's the only hope I have to survive because many others like me don't make it and I want to avoid this fate. I don't want to be treated like a subhuman.

posts.com:
>>28167513
I've had this exact problem. It feels like a syndrome that people don't talk about very much. The thing is that most people do things just as bad or worse than you do but don't care. I think it boils down to hating yourself but also secretly also hating others. Most people have the opposite problem of blaming all their problems but deep down. hating themselves too. There's a lot of positive in being naturally self-critical, but you ofc have to balance that.

There are two angles that I've found helpful that in combination have in effect cured me. First, you have to accept your past failings and realize that most people are quite selfish. This will take time, but it's worth it in the long run.

Second, you can't always play life on defense. You have to do things that improve your self image or else you're just minimizing the bad. You have to practice being nice to your partners and then recognizing what you did as good. Do a nice deed for a stranger. Perhaps the easiest thing to do is volunteer work. Try setting some concrete goals for yourself.

The end goal is to be positively sociable and reward yourself for doing it. I've personally gone from being an awkward and self-hating guy to being the chilliest guy in the room that occasionally does some good for others.

Look into priming:
>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priming_(psychology)

My guess is that your essentially trying to prepare yourself for a perceived inevitable rejection, or loss, by doing absolutely fucktarded things. You're being a coward and dishonest, and in your refusal to accept reality, as in the fact that you will be rejected, you will lose someone important to you, etc. you're developing a neurosis or some kind of complex around rejection and loss.

Try to mentally take yourself to uncomfortable scenarios, and see how you respond. Use your responses to find out more about yourself:

1). Imagine how you would feel if you had lots of people who loved and supported you: friends, girlfriends, wives, children, family, etc. How does that make you feel?
2). Imagine the opposite. Every new person instinctually distrusts and despises you. People you already know openly express their longstanding disdain for your behavior. How do you intend to react? What do you expect to accomplish from behaving that way?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28167597
>BDSM community always makes sure to get the arrangement in formal writing before proceeding
Not really.

There should be a negotiation before any scene where you go over some reasonable subset of
>Desired activity, intensity level, and length
>Kinks and toys/implements you want to include
>The mood you want and tone for dom and sub
>Activities you’re most excited and nervous for
>Goals, including feelings, for the scene
>Whether and what sexual activity you want
>Your nutrition and hydration status if it's relevant to what you're doing
>Safe words and stop mechanisms and their meaning
>An exit plan if you use your safe word or are triggered
>Any aftercare you need in the short and longterm
But formal written BDSM contracts aren't worth the paper they're printed on. Even ignoring that they're outside the norm so partners are unlikely to agree to them, they don't offer any kind of legal force, are typically mostly just used as their own form of kink for master-slave types, and offer you basically zero legal protection in an actual courtroom, ESPECIALLY assuming OP's hypothetical situation where your partner intends to lie about what happened afterwards.

Even if they dead-to-rights agree she signed the contract, it won't help you. It could be describing a hypothetical scene that had nothing to do with what actually played out in real life. She could claim the scene started as described but consent was revoked during the scene and you kept going anyways. Assuming no witnesses were present before or after the scene and you went non-digital, she could claim the contract was for a previous sex encounter and you're bringing it out now to defend yourself post-rape.

Yes, you want to have at least some written notional records that you two both engage in consensual BDSM should issues arise, with perhaps a brief text message chain between you two positively confirming this, but for most people, contracts don't offer much protection and are wildly overkill.

literally just supplement with online contacts - but the key is to do this only on a desktop pc at home.

you're modelling good boundaries with tech for the people you meet irl this way also, and you stand out to people who use apps and who don't use apps as someone who... doesn't use apps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28167866
headphones or would you be willing to try earbuds?
sony wf-1000xm4 have really good ANC (active noise-cancelling). they're pricey at $250-300 and wireless aren't as good as wired but the upside is the ANC. Also, in general, stop listening to stuff at high volume, even if you have tinnitus you're only going to risk it getting worse in addition to permanent hearing loss which will also only make the tinnitus worse.

As for lifestyle changes, idk how often you have to be out and about but i feel it, after a brief peace during quarantine where nobody was on the streets, I've longed for those days to return, but that fantasy won't come true. I honestly just go out less. I go for walks at night, I try to do everything in the early morning or late at night, I work from home, I work out in a home gym, and I practice meditation/mindfulness to better tolerate annoying stimuli. Other shit like getting more rest, exercising, eating well, etc. will improve your mood which will make you perceive sensory stressors less intensely in the first place and have you in a better headspace to keep your cool. hope this helps

posts.sub: How can I accept that I won't make friends?
posts.com:
I'm a zoomer (18yo woman, I posted my photo here a few weeks ago, I'm on the lower end of average) and I don't have any friends, I don't think I will at this point. I've had no friends since I was out of primary school, and am a complete outcast. I don't have anything to talk about because I don't do anything outside of school/work/being in my room, and I'm so bitter from spending years alone and jealous of others that I look down upon most of them, anyway (I know this is bad, I really do need to work on it). Most of all, even without my resentment, I can't bear being around people, as awful as that sounds; I hate how people my age act, most of my area are chavs or 'alt', so from the start there's not really any place that a more traditional person such as myself may fit into. Maybe it's cruel, but I don't particularly care for editing my face multiple times to post on social media, nor do I care for whatever nonbinary discourse the 'alt' students in my classes are debating, I think it's all ridiculous and if that makes me a bigot then so be it.

I don't have any online friends, I always felt like an intruder walking into Discord servers the few times I tried and the whole thing is laughable anyway. There are few social events where I am, either; I'm in a city in England not too far from London and of course, there are many nightclubs and such, but no places for quieter people. I'm not even sure where I'd go to socialise. In the unlikely chance I get a boyfriend, he would be my only source of interaction and I wouldn't want to impose that on him. I don't have any conditions aside from (diagnosed) PTSD from a childhood of parental bullying and anorexia, but those barely of those factor into this. PTSD definitely made me hesitant to interact with people but even after working to get over it, the way I feel about this hasn't changed.

Apologies for the long post, I just wanted to cover every base.

I'm a 19 yo zoomer from the UK too and have a very similar situation. Haven't had friends since I left secondary school, and even then I wasn't part of any social groups, just had a few people I spoke with occasionally. Towards the end of secondary school it got so bad that I spent my entire breaks in the toilets just to save myself the embarassment.

I think upbringing has a lot to do with it. My mum was raised by very controlling parents who didn't really let her out much, and no surprise, she gave me the same exact upbringing. On the few attempts I do try to go out she will do whatever she can to control it in one way or another (offering to give me a lift when I already said I will bike or take the bus, constantly messaging me etc.). I wasn't allowed to walk to school by myself until Year 7 despite our school being a 5 minute walk around the block. I was always the last kid waiting at the end of the day.

And my dad was the complete opposite, just never really there. My only memories of him as a kid are of him drinking and swearing at me or my mum and blasting loud music by himself every Friday night. A boy without a good father figure is a waste of existence in my opinion. I wouldn't wish that fate on anyone.

The worst thing I can remember them doing is, one day I went to the shops down the street with some kids from my school, it was the one time I actually tried to do something by myself, and when I got back and my parents found out my dad walked to my friend's house and yelled at their parents. Who the fuck does that? Fucking embarassing. I didn't understand it back then, but I think now I realised that that moment probably sealed my fate forever.

And now here I am, doing nothing but working and making shit music. I don't resent anyone or despise others in the way people like me tend to. I just recognize that someone like me just isn't made for the world. There is no fixing anything or getting better. I will always be like this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Decided to put even mor of my time into this thread.

I honestly think that you have certain expectations of others that are unecessarily harsh, especially directed at your age group. I get that you may not want to approach others and accept that it is not on them to approach you. But social interaction mainly occurs during activities of regular every day life. The rest is usually contrived via group settings like parties, clubs, pubs, festivals etc. So if you reject both mundane and contrived means of interaction then this may be enough to accept not making friends at all.

But I am not convinced you do accept that. Your friend here has attracted some discourse and you're socialising. I suggest you aim to do this regularly either online or offline.

Finally, friendships and all relationships are about trust. And you don't seem to be full of that. Sure it needs to be earned but the way you generalise others puts you at risk of shutting people out unintentionally.

Yes, it is absolutely alright. If you try to make moves on a woman and you're not creepy about it the worst thing that will happen almost all of the time is just that she is flattered but is not receptive. I know there's a meme out there that "creepy is just when an unattractive guy does it" but that's not actually true in my experience. In reality, creepy is just when a guy hits on a woman in too awkward a way and/or he is oblivious to her responses and does not take them into account. If you hit on a woman in a fun way, meaning that you are doing it in a way that is fun for you and playful, and you pay attention to her response and do not try to escalate if her response is completely negative, then you won't come off as creepy. Most of the time women's rejections to guys who have basic social skills are not complete rejections of the "go away" type, they are more just of the "I'm kinda flattered but I don't want to pursue this" type. Sometimes women who reject you in that way will change their minds later. Basically, it's not creepy to hit on women if:
1) You are playful and fun about it as opposed to being dreadfully serious "you are my true love blah blah blah" mode
and
2) You pay attention to her response and if it is not positive then you back off a bit and give her some space
Making moves on women in itself is not creepy at all, it is only creepy if you are either dreadfully serious about it, which makes her feel that you might be weird stalker obsessed guy, or if you ignore her responses and try to plow through and monopolize her attention too much when she is sending signals that at the moment she doesn't want that. By the nature of making moves on women, you have to step into her reality a bit and put your cards on the table. As long as you're having fun, not taking things including her reactions too seriously, but also are aware of her reactions and back off a bit if she isn't feeling it, you're not going to come off as creepy to her.

You are forgetting the human element here, that unpredictability that comes from a lifetime of her experiences, day to day struggles, and even the particular events of that day, that prevents any perfect algorithm for seduction from ever being developed. You can do everything right, but because an arbitrary event occurred today, or 10 years ago, you're disqualified. And that disqualification might permanent, and sometimes only temporary. But play that out over enough attempts and the arbitrary factors matter less and the strength of your game matters more. In sales this is also a problem, thus it's well known in the sales world that a mediocre script run 100 times is superior to a great script run 10 times.

Now, if there's a problem with how you act, that needs to be addressed.
unfortunately it's hard to diagnose over this format.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Since I went sober a little over two months ago (had a year sober before a 3 day relapse two months ago) my brain is just not right. Just completing small daily tasks takes complete focus to accomplish. Every time I drive it feels as if I have just got my license and need to be extra careful. Carrying on a conversation is a struggle, I forget simple words as if I’m trying to recall something. Everything seems so forced and pointless. The steps I was so use to in my daily life seem soooo foreign at times. I have to go over the process of showering in my head before I do it. Hanging out with friends is a chore, getting the girlfriend of my dreams now means nothing. My emotions are diminished to the point I feel basically nothing. Empathy for the people my addiction has hurt doesn't bother me at all anymore. I see the pain I’ve caused, yet I feel nothing. I have close connections but don't love these people in my life. The only thing I feel is hate for myself and the people closest to me.

I know this all sounds cringe but I can't articulate it any other way. I know a month clean isn’t very long for allowing the body to readjust its self back to a “normal” state, but I have been through wd’s before (2yrs sober at one point) and it feels like this is the case every time. Brief moments of hope after getting initially sober don't last for me. I feel like my brain only works high. I've tried suboxone and I'd rather not be tethered to methadone, I need the chaos of addiction it allows me to be satisfied in completing normal and healthy necessary tasks. Everyday I look for improvement, and most those days I am disappointed, tired, and depressed. I exercise daily, reach out to my 'friends', take good care of myself but I feel like I'm putting on a mask for a part of me that should care but doesn't.

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28101153
A job change isn't going to fix your life. You need an entire lifestyle change. I'm 26 and went through something similar around 24. I'm going to recommend something cliche, but it fucking works for reasons I will elaborate on. Get in shape. If you are fat lose weight. If you are skinny hit the gym. Yes it's a physical thing but we are mostly after the mental benefits. When you improve physically it does several things mentally (arguably it has more mental benefits than physical). First is you learn to be disciplined. This obviously effects every aspect of life. You need discipline to escape NEETdom. Next it will give you a taste of that "better life". You will see hard effort turn into tangible rewards that you can be proud of. This can set off a chain reaction into other aspects of life you feel are lacking. Next is confidence. You will be more confident in your self and your abilities and it could be enough of a boost to get you to pounce on opportunities you otherwise would have missed by being passive. Perhaps most important of all it will get you out of the house and give you a hobby that isn't doing anything for you. This can lead to meeting new people and gives you a common interest hobby that you can share and engage with most people over. Don't forget other people will treat you better too.

All of that doesn't even take into account the physical aspects that also play a role in mental health. You would likely see an increase in certain hormones such as testosterone and a decrease in things like estrogen. These hormones play a huge role in mental health and having screwed up hormones probably play a huge role in depression and the like. In my opinion physical improvement is the number one best thing you can do if you are unhappy with your life because it lays the foundation for everything else. This is coming from someone who was fat basically my entire life and was well on my way to being an eternal neet. Getting /fit/ is what saved me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's pretty simple to fix this mate. Set a goal. A simple, achievable goal that has a few steps to it and might take awhile to achieve. Getting a job or a better job for example.

Define what the goal is specifically. For example continuing with the job idea, let's say your goal was to get a new job in the role just above yours with an 8% increase in salary.

So you've set a goal and defined what it is specifically/what achieving the goal looks like.

Now break down the steps required to achieve that goal. Do you need to put in more time at work? Learn a new skill? Get a new qualification? Get yourself on the radar of whoever could give you such a promotion in a positive way? Do you need to work on your resume? Linkedin? Clean up socials? Etc. Work out all of the things that need to be done between where you are where you want to be.

Some steps might have steps of their own to achieve before you can complete the step. For example you might need to do a bridging course before getting a qualification you need.

Order them out in the chronicle order they have to be done in.

Now, set about doing those things one by one. Stick to it, don't shy away, don't stop just because you got bored, stick to it no matter what. If an obstacle gets in your way, map out a route around it that gets you where you want to me. Stick to it.

Then, with hard work and perseverance you'll eventually achieve your goal and reap it's rewards.

Now, set a new goal, rinse and repeat. Congratulations you're a functional human being.

>>28165381
keep your W-2. do not throw it away after you file your taxes. file your taxes before the deadline (like april 15th) using the information that is on your w-2.
it shows you how much money you earned, how much you paid towards taxes and social security, how much you paid towards employer retirement, etc. you use it when you file your taxes because they want to make sure you've paid enough.
depending on your deduction and how much you paid in federal/state taxes vs how much you're required to pay, you'll either get a refund, or if you owe more, you'll have to pay that when you file

>>28161728
Tne US has literally hundreds of universities, with widely varying standards. Do some reseach to pick out the few you are interested in and learn about their standards.

Broadly speaking, it is usueally easier to transfer into a university than to be accepted as a beginner. But be aware that not all your courses will be accepted as equivalent to US classes, and there will be other requirements - including classes not in your field - you'll have to meet. Count on losing at least a year to make-ip classes.

do you attend in-person college? if so the most convenient thing to do is to get a job somewhere on campus. working so close to where you attend classes is very convenient and should be manageable unless you're in a graduate program. plus they will typically being more flexible with your student schedule.
in general though, you just have to be better at managing your time. most majors do not require more than 8hrs of work a day, so you have plenty of hours out of the day to get in some part time work. working in college can be a grind, but if you accept the time commitment and manage your classes well (and dont procrastinate), it's not that bad.
explore adderall or other prescriptions if you're struggling. countless professionals are reliant on stimulants so don't feel bad about it.

>>28165884
probably like 22, 25, 27, and all throughout 28-29, with noticeable dips. I've started taking caffeine to get through my workouts in the last several months which i didn't ever need sups or anything before
I'm sort of obsessive by nature so I've had lots of blood tests throughout my life and a couple of times I've had T levels at 330ish ng/dL but i've had many more results around 770+ and my doc assured me that it's still normal even if that result was closer to the lower end of normal, and that it fluctuates a lot anyway. Also all my other blood panel stuff is normal, so idk what physically is going on other than general aging. Objectively I'm at the strongest I've ever been in my life but subjectively, I always *feel* like a zombie barely dragging my feet. I get less horny, I get sleeping spells where I just crash for hours, I often give up my workouts after the compounds and fucking can't do cardio anymore

idk if i have any advice. you could try caffeine, 400mg 15 minutes before a workout gives me like a 3 hour boost to push through workout and then get some work done after but it hasn't been the miracle drug my regular coffee drinker friends and family have told me it is. Eat clean, sleep in as solid of blocks as you can, drink lots of water, exercise, and try not to lie down or sit down as much throughout the day as I notice that sort of *induces* tiredness and makes it even harder to pull yourself out of that slump, do all this if you aren't already, but i'm sorry i don't have the answer either other than shrugging and chalking it up to age

Feeling overwhelmed by more than one person at a time is extreme shyness/social anxiety or it can be a manifested symptom of mental illness such as autism or episodic mental illness such as general anxiety or clinical depression.

If you aren't larping your boyfriend isn't cheating because you missed a text. He's cheating because you have no place being in a relationship in the emotional state you're in and need to get that sorted out BEFORE you try to date.

Being in a relationship with someone shouldn't inhibit personal growth in either participant nor prevent either from experiencing life in the way they otherwise would. Right now you're doing that to your boyfriend and that's why he's cheating. End your relationship and focus on fixing yourself.

posts.sub: Help a Canadian Pick a Degree
posts.com:
I’m a 1st year engineering student at Queen’s.

In about a month, I need to pick the engineering discipline I want to major in.

Should I pick computer engineering or mining engineering?

I know more about computer engineering but I think I’m equally interested in both.

I want to pick my degree based on earning potential, work-life balance, and possibility of relocation to the US.

Below are some observations I made (my observations could be wrong):

Prospects:
>In Canada, mining engineers earn more than computer (hardware and software) engineers.

>In Canada, there is greater demand for mining engineers.

>A computer engineer is more likely to get an American job than a mining engineer.

>A computer engineer working in the US will earn a LOT more than a Canadian mining engineer or really MOST other Canadian professionals.

>Canada is a very expensive country. Mining engineers can live in low cost of living areas.

>Computer engineers generally live in high cost of living areas unless they move out of Canada.

Work-Life Balance:
>Mining engineers either work on a rotational basis (2 weeks on 2 weeks off) or work 9-5 5 days a week.

>Computer engineers usually work 9-5 5 days a week but if sufficiently skilled can work remotely.

>Mining engineers rarely need to update their skills.

>Computer engineers, especially those working in software, need to constantly update their skills.

Housing:
>Mining engineers can afford homes in undesirable locations within Canada.

>Computer engineers cannot afford homes within Canada.

>Computer engineers can afford homes in desirable locations within the US if they are able to move to the US.

Skills:
>I started programming in my late teens so I am not an exceptional programmer. However, I am eager to improve.

>Idk much about mining but I feel that you’re not expected to know anything prior to starting mining engineering.

International Opportunities:
>CEs are more likely to get a TN or even H-1B visa and move to the US.
